author: Stéphane
title: Genome App - Monetise your Genome
description: 30 million people have had their genome sequenced. Our Gene app will enable them share their DNA for money, to help medical research.

assessments.note: This proposal has great potential to combine two cutting edge fields (human genomics and blockchain). The implementation part of it is lacking as the next review sections explain. However, it certainly meets the criteria of DApps & Integration if you can pull it off. I am personally deciding about what sort of genetic testing I should have before having children. One aspect I haven't fully considered is who will be utilizing that data and who can be trusted. I would love to see a world where health sciences can benefit and the patient can maintain control over their genetic data.

The idea is good. It solves security issues that arise with potential sharing of personal DNA sequences to third parties without consent. A good example that is found in the proposal is that there is an option to share but a portion of a sequence instead of the entire sequence. 
It gives users the possibility of choosing in which research their data will be used. 
There is also the ability to scale to a global level explained in the slides. Yet it is unclear if this is realisable in a timeframe of 6 months.
The proposal  outlines a very interesting use case for Cardano. The financial incentives for sharing genome data could easily onboard many users to the Cardano ecosystem.
Not clear what would actually be produced
Great idea that could effectively address the challenge. The proposer has identified a suitable problem and has started to propose a viable solution.

Selective sharing of own Genome sequence with the facility to earn money looks like a revolutionary proposal. This has potential to encourage people to get their genome sequences which can earn passive income at the same time provide vital data to the scientific community. This will be a great use case for the blockchain as whole.

Your personal experience (life-sciences and tech executive) is impressive, but the NFT/blockchain parts are lacking. Also, there is no breakdown of how the $50,000 will be allocated on this proposal. I do see the 1-3 month($35,000), 3-8 month($155,000), and 8-12 month($1,325,000) breakdowns on the 24 slide download. I believe this request should be for $35,000 to more closely align with your presentation, but it should also be broken down directly on the proposal. I do not believe the NFT route will apply to secure medical data, but do think there is a blockchain use case here.

The proposer originates from a medical tech background. Judging from the slides, the plan is clearly laid out in detail, yet misses some factors to correctly determine the feasibility of the project. 
It seems that the project is already partially finished. Is this the case? 
It's not entirely clear who would perform the work to develop this. 
There is previous collaboration mentioned with engineers. Will they do this task or is the proposer looking for people from within the community? If so, using the seek-tags can improve trust and clarity.

Feasibility: 3/5
From the attached presentation, the proposer seems to have a good grasp of  of the opportunity and the industry. They claim to have lead startups related to genomics. Links to evidence such as Linked in profile would strengthen their case.  I see a lack of evidence for the proposer's understanding of how Cardano would be implemented on a technical level.  It sounds like a potential application for Atala Prism, but this is not discussed. I think more technical research needs to be done or presented before the project will appear feasible.
No detailed plan on what would actually be produced, thus unlikely to be successful. Evidence to back up proposers claimed experience would be good (LinkedIn profile?)

The author appears to have the skillset to manage a project but will require a team that have not been identified as part of the proposal. This makes it difficult to gauge the likelihood of a successful implementation. The plan is lacking any sort of timeline, examples or budget breakdown.
The proposer is CEO of GenomSys and the company has verifiable core competence in this industry. The company should be able to manage the proposal in a professional manner.

The technology described in the slide download is impressive "Our mobile technology , powered by ISO/IEC
23092 (MPEG-G), allows individuals to share
their genomic information in one quick
transaction". The entire slide presentation is well designed and packed with useful information on your tech and the billion dollar genomic data industry. It is lacking a clear link to the Cardano blockchain. Slide 23 "Because you now control your personal health data, you can share and be paid for that information, through our secure and private health data market exchange" has a pic of Cardano logo, but does not even mention how you plan to integrate.

As the proposer mentioned, the roadmap is not worked out in detail yet. 
The requested funding in the slides does not correspond with the amount asked in the proposal. The origin of this seems to be the long term vision of the proposer. To improve this I'd suggest to break down the funding requests in clearly defined portions with a goal set for each fund requested and add in detail where the funding would go to. (Why 50k USD? What portion of that amount goes where?)
There is a potential risk not defined: DNA needs to get sequenced by an external party. Which assurance is there that this data does not leak before getting converted to an NFT?

Auditability: 2/5
The proposers offer no specific timeline, no breakdown of fund allocation,  and no other auditable goals.  I think they concept is a really good one, but it is very large in scope. To make a convincing proposal, a detailed development plan showing an understanding of the technological requirements should be included.
$50,000 to research an idea seems expensive. A detailed plan with milestones should be produced.

As stated earlier this is a great idea but severely lacking in detail for a proposal. The author would do well to refine the finer points of who will be required for the Dapp development, and budget to at least MVP level. At present we are being asking to provide significant funds and trust that it will come to fruition. I'm not saying the proposer could not do this but need further information to assure me he can. Recommend further collaboration with the community, revision of funds requested and reapplication.
The proposal has been presented in a precise manner with clear goals in each step. The proposal is an open book and is easily auditable.

solution: Due to concerns over who has access to their DNA many people refrain from sharing it. We authorise access to specific portions with Cardano.
experience: I am an experienced life-sciences and tech executive, having led several successful Startups ranging from audio compression to genomics.
